content: Fans of Sally Rooney’s novel “Normal People” are devoted types. They tend to hold the book’s central mismatched-but-also-kind-of-perfect-together couple, Marianne and Connell, close to their hearts. So adapting the book for TV came with risks. “It was a big leap of faith,” Rooney told The Hollywood Reporter earlier this year about casting the show, “that we were going to find people who would just get it, and would know exactly how to communicate that friction between the inner life and the outer world.” Daisy Edgar-Jones and Paul Mescal have received widespread acclaim for their performances in the 12-part series on Hulu. Some of the praise for the show came from James Poniewozik, The Times’s chief television critic, who called it a “gorgeous, melancholy series” starring leads who “have so much chemistry you may need lab goggles.” Poniewozik recently joined The Times’s three book critics — Dwight Garner, Parul Sehgal and Jennifer Szalai — for a discussion I moderated about the show, the novel, the art of adaptation and more. — John Williams, Daily Books Editor

content: BARBER SHOP CHRONICLES Stream on Nationaltheatre.org.uk. Barbershops are portrayed as communal spaces where patrons hang out and talk about politics, relationships and masculinity — and maybe also get their hair cut — in Inua Ellams’s “Barber Shop Chronicles,” a play that was a hit in London in 2017. The story bridges six barbershops in six cities, focusing on conversations in each shop over the course of a day. The fleet-footed script is based on recordings of conversations Ellams made in barbershops in Africa and London. “The men were just laughing whilst talking about really crazy issues,” Ellams said in an interview with The New York Times last year. “I had one rule: If a topic comes up three times in three different countries, then it has to go into the play.” This production, recorded during the show’s run at the National Theater in London, is streaming until late next week as part of a series of free programming being offered during the pandemic.

The story doesn’t really make sense, which is why, when asked about Obamagate, President Trump couldn’t describe it. title: ‘A Lot of Bad News Out There’: Parenting in a Pandemic
description: A mother balances coverage of tsunamis, plane crashes, bombings and other tragedies with life at home during a coronavirus lockdown.
content: BANGKOK — I didn’t want to be that parent, the one who talks about how when I was a child I had to walk uphill both ways, in the snow, just to get to school.
source.name: The New York Times
